title: Question 7

children: A 43-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for confusion and a 1-week history of yellow skin. She consumes 12 beers daily.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F); blood pressure is 120/50 mm Hg, pulse rate is 100/min, and respiration rate is 24/min. Her sclerae are icteric and skin is jaundiced. Tender hepatomegaly is present. She has asterixis and is oriented to person only. No source of infection has been identified. Maddrey discriminant function score is 35.
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows hepatomegaly, minimal ascites, liver echogenicity, and no biliary stones or ductal dilation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Prednisolone is the treatment for severe alcoholic hepatitis, defined as a Maddrey discriminant function score of 32 or greater or the presence of hepatic encephalopathy.
Patients with alcoholic hepatitis treated with prednisolone who do not respond after 7 days should have the prednisolone discontinued; otherwise, prednisolone should be continued for 28 days.

). This patient has acute alcoholic hepatitis, a distinct clinical syndrome of severe steatohepatitis in the setting of chronic alcoholic liver disease. Acute alcoholic hepatitis often presents with fever, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and leukocytosis. The short-term mortality rate is high. In severe cases, as defined by a Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) score of 32 or greater or the presence of hepatic encephalopathy, treatment with prednisolone can be considered. The MDF score = 4.6 (prothrombin time [s] – control prothrombin time [s]) + serum total bilirubin (mg/dL). A meta-analysis of randomized studies showed that glucocorticoids were effective in reducing short-term mortality by 46%. This treatment should be considered in patients who do not have evidence of infection or gastrointestinal bleeding. This patient's MDF score is 35, and prednisolone should be considered.
